p: Postinfectious reactive airway disease/asthma. Following acute infection, viruses can cause chronic sequelae, such as postinfectious recurrent wheezing in 40–50 % of RSV, hMPV, and RhV patients. Severe RSV bronchiolitis is associated with an increased risk of hospitalization for asthma in the short term (Papenburg and Boivin 2010). Some suggest that greater severity of RSV bronchiolitis may reflect an intrinsic genetic predisposition for asthma. hMPV is detected in approximately 8–9 % of children with recurrent wheezing and BoV in approximately 5–6 % (Smuts et al. 2008). Specifically, hMPV bronchiolitis carries a fivefold risk of future development of asthma compared to control patients hospitalized for gastroenteritis (Brodzinski and Ruddy 2009).
